page.title: 08Wepre Hall
page.content: {Wepre Hall}was{rebuilt}in 1770 by a man called{Edward Jones.}They employed several servants who wore a distinctive black uniform. Edward Jones died in 1815 and his son Trevor Owen Jones took over. During its' time Wepre has had a number of visitors. One a royalist, Edward Morgan stayed at the hall during the civil war. Another royalist who stayed there was Lord Petrie who took refuge after the defeat of the royalists at{Rowton Moor in 1645. One of the most famous people to stay there was{Charles Kingsley}the author of the Water Babies. Local people remember a pets graveyard in the garden, but the gravestones were moved to another pets graveyard in {BALA}after a lot were vandalised. Before the hall was knocked down in 1966 it was converted into flats for a time. {Gillian Lambert.
